EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California (Metropolitan) treats and distributes drinking water to member water agencies throughout Southern California. Metropolitan provides approximately 40 percent of the drinking water used by nearly 19 million people living on the southern California coastal plain between Ventura County and the Mexican border.

Disinfection is a critical process used by Metropolitan in the treatment of its drinking water.  Disinfection helps to protect public health by killing pathogens in the water and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases.  The use of chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water and wastewater has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of the previous century.  While many of Metropolitans facilities have switched to ozone as a primary disinfectant, Metropolitan will still continue to utilize bulk chlorine for residual disinfection and as a backup disinfectant to ozone at all of its water treatment plants.  Metropolitan currently utilizes bulk chlorine for disinfection at all of its water treatment plants, including the Joseph Jensen Water Treatment Plant (Jensen Plant).

As one might expect from its superior disinfection properties, chlorine is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling chlorine can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  Metropolitan regards safe practices in the storing and usage of chlorine to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with chlorine. To further safe practices, Metropolitan has constructed a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility at Jensen Plant to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers.

Jensen Plant's chlorine storage and usage process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule (RMPR) and also to the California Accidental Relea

se Prevention (CalARP) Program regulation.  Both of these regulations require submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an emergency.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
-Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
-General facility and regulated substances information.
-Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
-Five-year accident history summary.
-Emergency response program summary.
-Planned changes to improve safety.

An RMP for the Jensen Plant Chlorination Facility has been prepared and is being submitted to the EPA and Los Angeles City Fire Department in June 2024, to comply with the five-year RMP update requirement.

The information required in the RMP Executive Summary is provided below for the Chlorine System at the Jensen Plant.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Metropolitans accidental release prevention policy for chlorine and aqueous ammonia involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's RMP Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response.

The Metropolitan Jensen Plant is a non-responding facility and, as such, does not have an emergency response plan.  Jensen Plant management has prepared an Emergency Action Plan to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  This emergency action plan is coordinated with local response agencies (Los

Angeles City Fire Department).  Jensen Plant has had an excellent safety record of chlorine use.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The Joseph Jensen Water Treatment Plant (Jensen Plant) is located at 13100 Balboa Boulevard in Granada Hills, California.  The plant is situated south of the Golden State Freeway (I-5) and Antelope Valley Freeway (14) junction.  The facility was constructed in 1972 and covers 232 acres.  The plant is designed to treat drinking water, including disinfection with chlorine.  The facility stores and uses chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the RMPR and CalARP Program rules, as well as the Federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.  

The Chlorine System at the Jensen Plant is composed of the following components: (1) a totally contained chlorine feed system to receive, store, and deliver liquid chlorine to the evaporators, chlorine expansion vessels, associated piping and valving, leak sensors and monitors, and instrumentation, (2) totally contained evaporators to convert the chlorine to gas for use in the chlorinators (evaporator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (3) totally contained chlorinators to regulate flow of chlorine gas under vacuum to the ejectors (chlorinator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (4) ejectors to mix the chlorine gas with service water and inject chlorine solution at application points throughout the plant, and (5) chlorine gas treatment systems for capture and neutralization of an accidental chlorine release in the contained areas (scrubbers, caustic soda, fans, pumps, and associated piping and valving).

The chlorine storage vessels (railcars) are totally contained in the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility storage bays.

The process flow for the Chlorine System begins at the liquid chlorine angle valves located on the storage vessels in each storage bay, conne

cted by flexible metallic hose to the fixed piping system.  Liquid chlorine is transferred by its own pressure from an on-line storage vessel in each storage bay to one or more evaporators in each evaporator room.

Each evaporator uses an electrically heated water bath to vaporize the liquid chlorine.  The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine gas (under vacuum) through venturi eduction to the ejectors.  The ejectors are located at various points throughout the facility, and introduce chlorine (under vacuum) into service water to form chlorine solution that subsequently mixes with the water supply at different stages of the treatment process for disinfection purposes.

The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility (CCHF) is continuously monitored in the control room by video cameras, process condition transmitters (pressure, flow, etc.) and chlorine leak detectors. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the storage bays, evaporator rooms, chlorinator room, pipe tunnels and ejector cabinets.  Based on the concentration and location of chlorine detected, the leak detection system will activate a succession of safety measures, beginning with visual and audible alarms, the start-up of the chlorine neutralization system and shut down of the normal ventilation system, and finally, automatically closing the storage vessel liquid chlorine angle valve.  The alarms are annunciated at the chlorine alarm panel as well as at the operators console in the control room.  Once alerted, fully trained personnel will respond to assess the chlorine leak.  In addition, each storage vessel valve connecting to the process is provided with a remotely actuated (pneumatic) emergency shutoff system.  In case of a major chlorine leak, chlorine supply can be stopped almost instantaneously by actuating the shutoff system, automatically or manually from any of three control panels: unloading platform, chlorine maintenance room, or control room.  Emergency showers and eyewash stations are a

lso provided throughout the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility including the scrubber system.

A packed-bed chlorine gas scrubber system, consisting of two parallel scrubber units, is provided to neutralize an accidental release of chlorine gas from either storage bay, evaporator room, or the chlorinator room.  Caustic soda (~20% concentration) is used as the scrubbing media.

The chlorine pressure reducing valves, leak detectors, safety systems and computer control system are connected to the uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system.  In the event power is lost at the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  The water treatment plant has an emergency generator system, which provides backup power to run the plant, including the Chlorine System and scrubber units, in the event of a power failure.

The control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through guarded security gates, which are closed after regular hours when the plant is patrolled by security guards.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is monitored by video cameras from the Control Room and has door alarms.  Process storage areas are further secured with a badge entry system by authorized employees only.

Finally, no chlorine releases that caused or could have caused a safety or health hazard or property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred at the Jensen Plant during the last five years.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Jensen Plants accidental release prevention program complies with all RMP, CalARP and PSM requirements and is based on the following key elements:
-Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
-Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
-Comprehensive preventive maintenance pr

ogram.
-Performance of process hazard analysis of process, equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
-Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
-Use of accurate and effective operating and maintenance procedures, written, reviewed and certified annually with the participation of the operators, plant specialists, mechanics, managers, PSM/RMP compliance staff and technical writers.
-High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff, plus job-based, tailored training and plant oversight/escorts for all visitors and contractors working in or near the chlorine process area(s).
-Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, auditing programs and emergency action plans using qualified staff.

Hazard-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, chlorine containment and automated scrubbing system to capture and neutralize a chlorine release, and remotely controlled shutoff devices on the chlorine storage.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine. This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets (SDS).

Equipment safety information is meticulously compiled on the chlorine process.  Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Metropolitan also has procedures in place to update

process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information outdated.

Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1991, 1994, 1995, 1998, 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020 detailed process hazard analyses (PHAs) were conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures.  All recommended actions during the previous PHAs to further improve the chlorine safety have been resolved.

A seismic walkthrough of the chlorination facility was completed in June 2023 based on Region 1 LEPC CalARP Guidance.  Recommendations were provided to Jensen Plant staff for evaluation and implementation.

Operating Procedures

Jensen Plant management maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the chlorine process.  The Jensen Plant ensures effective operating and maintenance practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOP) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  The operating procedures include receiving cargo tanks, connection and disconnection for chlorine cargo tanks, chlorine system startup and shutdown during normal operations, chlorine transfer operations, chlorine system startup and shutdown during abnormal operations, chlorine system startup and shutdown for maintenance, emergency operating procedures, and scrubber system operations.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations.  Jensen Plant management reviews procedures annually and updates them if necessary or whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Such an update and re-certification of operating procedures took place to incorporate changes in chlorine operations associated with the chlorine containment and scrubbing system.  Operating procedures will be developed and pu

t in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of chlorine equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.
 
Training 

Jensen Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Jensen Plant management ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  The Jensen Plant training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training, (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the chlorine process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine leak response, as provided in the operating procedures.

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the Jensen Plant management ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change procedures and/or Pre Startup Safety Review procedures.  

Jensen Plant management prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training.

Contractors

Metropolitan has procedures and policies in place that ensure that the contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work.  The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation o

f the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.  Jensen Plant operators, managers and EHS representatives hold contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area. Jensen Plant management controls access to the process areas and helps evaluate the contractor's safety performance with EHS representatives.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

Jensen Plant management ensures that a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  

Jensen Plant management maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The Jensen Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:
-Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.
-Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
-Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures; safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Jensen Plant management requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the covered process. Jensen Plant uses a permitting and training program to ensure hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine.

Metropolitan requires the Management of Change process to be completed for changes to the chlorine system tha

t are not considered as a replacement-in-kind.  Metropolitan PSM/RMP Management of Change Procedure HSE 108.5 describes the process that must be completed prior to implementing changes to the chlorine system.  The Management of Change process of Metropolitan provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions. This system allows Jensen Plant employees to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  Metropolitan management assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.  The last internal compliance audit was completed in May 2023.

Incident Investigation

Jensen Plant management investigates all incidents that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  If required, an investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added o

r used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.

Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that have caused or could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Jensen Plant during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

The Jensen Plant is a non-responding facility and, as such, does not have an emergency response plan.  The Jensen Plant has Technician Level HAZWOPER-trained plant employees who will respond only to incidental chlorine releases and will respond to emergency releases only to assess the situation and take defensive measures.  The Jensen Plant also includes employees trained in the Incident Command System, who can coordinate with and provide technical assistance to outside emergency responders.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external hazardous materials response agencies, such as the Los Angeles City Fire Department Hazardous Materials Response Team, will be called to handle a chlorine release.  Jensen Plant management coordinates routinely with local response agencies (Los Angeles City Fire Department) to help ensure that they are familiar with the Jensen Plant chlorine system and its emergency response requirements and that this is reflected in their Area Plans.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1991, 1994, 1995, 1998, 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020 when Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) were conducted under the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP), Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and Risk Management Program were prepared for the facility.  These recommended actions have been evaluated and implemented as required.
